ratingLevels.criteria: X-ray evidence of involvement of 2 or more major joints or 2 or more minor joint groups, with occasional incapacitating exacerbations
X-ray evidence with symptom combination of 2 or more major joints or 2 or more minor joint groups, with occasional incapacitating exacerbations and some limitation of motion

musculoskeletal.notes: Major joints: shoulder, elbow, wrist, hip, knee, ankle. Minor joints: fingers, toes.

ratingLevels.criteria: Satisfactory evidence of pain with use
X-ray evidence of involvement, with occasional incapacitating exacerbations

musculoskeletal.notes: Must establish service connection through injury or trauma

ratingLevels.criteria: Moderate limitation of motion
Marked limitation of motion
Ankylosis of the ankle in plantar flexion or in extreme dorsiflexion
Ankylosis of the ankle in dorsiflexion at more than right angle

musculoskeletal.notes: Flexion beyond 20°, or ankylosis in neutral position (0°) warrants 20% rating

ratingLevels.criteria: Mild
Moderate, weight-bearing line over or medial to great toe, inward bowing of tendo achillis, pain on use accentuated
Severe, weight-bearing line over or medial to great toe, inward bowing of tendo achillis, marked external rotation of os calcis
Pronounced; weight-bearing line over or medial to great toe, inward bowing of tendo achillis, marked external rotation of os calcis, severe on standing or walking
Bilateral or unilateral
Severe, bilateral
Unilateral, severe, with marked deformity, limitation of motion, and pain on manipulation and use
A mental condition has been formally diagnosed, but symptoms are not severe enough either to interfere with occupational and social functioning or to require continuous medication
Occupational and social impairment due to mild or transient symptoms which decrease work efficiency and ability to perform occupational tasks only during periods of significant stress
Occupational and social impairment with occasional decrease in work efficiency and intermittent periods of inability to perform occupational tasks
Occupational and social impairment with reduced reliability and productivity
Occupational and social impairment with deficiencies in most areas
Total occupational and social impairment

mental.notes: Must establish stressor occurred during service. Combat veterans have lower burden of proof.

Mild or transient symptoms during stress

Reduced reliability and productivity

ratingLevels.criteria: Asymptomatic but with documented sleep disorder breathing
Chronic daytime hypersomnolence
Requires use of breathing assistance device such as CPAP
Chronic respiratory failure with carbon dioxide retention, cor pulmonale, or requires tracheostomy

respiratory.notes: Most veterans with CPAP qualify for 50%. Must have sleep study.

ratingLevels.criteria: FEV-1 of 71- to 80-percent predicted, or; FEV-1/FVC of 71 to 80 percent, or; intermittent inhalational or oral bronchodilator therapy
FEV-1 of 56- to 70-percent predicted, or; FEV-1/FVC of 56 to 70 percent, or; daily inhalational or oral bronchodilator therapy or; inhalational anti-inflammatory medication

FEV-1 of 40- to 55-percent predicted, or; FEV-1/FVC of 40 to 55 percent, or; at least monthly visits to a physician for required care of exacerbations, or; intermittent (at least three per year) courses of systemic corticosteroids

FEV-1 less than 40-percent predicted, or; FEV-1/FVC less than 40 percent, or; more than one attack per week with episodes of respiratory failure, or; requires daily use of systemic (oral or parenteral) corticosteroid or immuno-suppressive medication
Diagnosed condition with no symptoms or mild symptoms
Mild symptoms with disturbances of bowel function with occasional episodes of abdominal distress
Severe; diarrhea, or alternating diarrhea and constipation, with more or less constant abdominal distress

digestive.notes: Often secondary to PTSD or anxiety

ratingLevels.criteria: Two of the following: epigastric distress, pyrosis, dysphagia, nausea, regurgitation, arm or shoulder pain, substernal or arm or shoulder pain, chronic cough, hoarseness, or nocturnal asthma
Persistently recurrent epigastric distress with dysphagia, pyrosis, and regurgitation
Severe; symptoms not controlled by continuous medication, with documented lifestyle impairment

digestive.notes: Often secondary to medications or sleep apnea

ratingLevels.criteria: No residual symptoms
Mild; subjective symptoms only
Moderate; neurobehavioral effects with mild cognitive or emotional dysfunction
Severe; neurobehavioral effects with significant cognitive or emotional dysfunction
Total; complete inability to function socially or occupationally

neurological.notes: Rate separately from mental health conditions under pyramiding exception

ratingLevels.criteria: Less frequent than once every 2 months on average
With very frequent completely prostrating and prolonged attacks productive of severe economic inadaptability
With characteristic prostrating attacks occurring on an average once a month over last several months
With very frequent completely prostrating and prolonged attacks productive of severe economic inadaptability

neurological.notes: Keep headache diary for evidence. Most common rating is 30% or 50%.

ratingLevels.criteria: Recurrent tinnitus

neurological.notes: Only one rating level (10%). Cannot be rated bilaterally.

ratingLevels.criteria: Diastolic pressure predominantly 100 or more
Diastolic pressure predominantly 110 or more, or; systolic pressure predominantly 200 or more
Diastolic pressure predominantly 120 or more with organic complications
Diastolic pressure predominantly 130 or more with severe organic complications

cardiovascular.notes: Can be secondary to PTSD, sleep apnea, medications

ratingLevels.criteria: Painful or unstable scars; multiple disfiguring scars
Deep scars, extensive scars that are painful, unstable, or attached to underlying tissue
Very extensive, deep scars covering large area
Massive scarring covering major portion of face or body

skin.notes: Rate based on pain, instability, size, and disfigurement
